---
title: Developing democracy and citizenship with literary texts about the First World
  War
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-59Q7INIY" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-59Q7INIY" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Torunn Synnøve Skjærstad conducted a study in a 9th grade English class in Norway to explore how literary texts about the First World War can enhance learning about democracy and citizenship. Students engaged with an illustrated book, two poems, and a novel excerpt, discussing them in groups using structured questions. These discussions aimed to connect the specific details of the texts to broader themes of democracy and citizenship, as outlined in Norway's national curriculum. The study suggests that using historical texts can improve students' historical literacy, which includes understanding history, thinking critically about it, and emotionally responding to it. This approach may help students develop a deeper awareness of history and improve their ability to think critically about historical events.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-59Q7INIY" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    First World War, Literary Texts, Democracy, Citizenship, Historical Literacy, English Classroom
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-59Q7INIY" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    This article reports on an empirical study that explores the interdisciplinary learning potential of literary texts about the First World War in the English classroom. In a 9th grade English class in Norway, learners responded to an illustrated book, two poems, and an excerpt from a novel about the war in learner-led group conversations structured by frameworks. The questions in the frameworks encouraged the learners to move from the particularity of the texts towards issues of the interdisciplinary topic of democracy and citizenship in the Norwegian national curriculum LK20. The theoretical position in this article builds on historical literacy, understood as historical awareness, critical historical thinking, and affective responses to texts about history. The texts offer opportunities for historical and interdisciplinary engagement, thus providing possibilities for developing aspects of historical literacy. Emphasising historical content through scaffolding may be beneficial for developing learners’ critical historical thinking and a deeper historical awareness. Encountering learners’ affective dimensions of historical literacy, individual responses might provide further insight. 
  </article>
